photo.title: Piazza dei Miracoli - Duomo (tilt shift)

photo.description: Piazza dei Miracoli The Cathedral, Pisa, Tuscany, Italy The monuments which transform a common name of square into the "Piazza dei Miracoli" are: the Cathedral, the Baptistery, the Bell or Leaning Tower and the Monumental Churchyard. This Romanesque cathedral was built at a time when Pisa was one of the most powerful maritime centers in Italy. The complex follows the early Christian pattern of separate structures for the church, baptistry, and bell tower, all of which are unified by the use of similar stone and the design of blind arcades and horizontal galleries. The cathedral plan is a Latin cross with a five-aisled nave, with a transept with apses at each end, and an elliptical crossing dome (erected later).
photo.tags: pisa italy tuscany cathedral architecture piazza tower
photo.title: Piazza dei Miracoli, Pisa, Tuscany, Italy

The complex follows the early Christian pattern of separate structures for the church, baptistry, and bell tower, all of which are unified by the use of similar stone and the design of blind arcades and horizontal galleries. The cathedral plan is a Latin cross with a five-aisled nave, with a transept with apses at each end, and an elliptical crossing dome (erected later).

photo.description: Talvez só isso justifique a torre estar de pé até hoje. Um milagre. Ela foi erguida para ser a torre do sino da catedral, mas logo que chegou no terceiro andar ela começou a se inclinar. Com isso, para tentar corrigir, os andares mais altos tem um lado mais alto que o outro (logo, além de ela estar torta, ela é torta). Na decada de 1990 foi feita a interdição dela e foi realizado um trabalho de estbilização nela que durou quase 10 anos. Depois disso, pela primeira vez na história da torre, ela parou de inclinar. Dizem que aguenta mais 200 anos.

photo.title: Postcard

photo.description: Pisa, 2 novembre 2007. A mezzogiorno si arriva in Piazza dei Miracoli. Ok. Uh! Bella la Torre! Un sogno nel cassetto spuntato. Curiosità! Saliamo? Informiamoci. Uh! Quindici euro a testa. Mh... Vabbè, dai: siam qui. Va bene. A che ora, scusi? Prossimo turno alle 16:40. Mi! Va ben, intanto guardiamo la Cattedrale, il Battistero e il Cimitero monumentale (quest'ultimo con ingresso gratuito vista la data). Ok. Sono passate circa cinque ore. Saliamo. Oh! La scala è in salita ma il primo pezzo praticamente è pianeggiante. Fico! :) Su, su e su. Azz! Azz! WOW! Che panorama. E... wow! Il tramonto! Incredibile. Ragazzi, soldi ben spesi, non c'è che dire. Meraviglia. Cronaca di un sogno realizzato in un modo talmente perfetto da superare di gran lunga la fantasia. Grazie.
photo.tags: italia italy pisa toscana irma tramonto sunset tetto roof top alto cima torredipisa torre tower leaning pendente panorama red rosso luce light incredible incredibile piazzadeimiracoli battistero udfaccioni lucky fortuna wonderful meraviglia perfect moment momento perfetto belltower bell campana architettura architecture old antico looking guardando

photo.description: Il battistero in piazza dei Miracoli a Pisa è uno dei massimi capolavori dell'arte romanico-gotica in Italia. La costruzione iniziò nel 1152 sotto la direzione dell'architetto e scultore Diotisalvi in stile romanico e dotato di cupola troncoconica. Proseguirono poi nel secolo successivo con Nicola Pisano, uno dei principali artisti del medioevo (quando venne trasformato in stile gotico con la loggia e la cupola emisferica che si sovrappose a quella piramidale) per terminare definitivamente nel XIV secolo. È il più grande battistero italiano. La circonferenza misura 107 metri, mentre la larghezza della muratura alla base è di due metri e mezzo e l'altezza di 55 metri. Pisa (Tuscany) - The baptistery of the Duomo The baptistery in the square of the Miracles in Pisa is one of the greatest masterpieces of medieval architecture in Italy. The construction began in 1152 under the direction of the architect and sculptor Diotisalvi in romanesque style and with tapered dome. Then the works continued into the next century with Nicola Pisano, one of the leading artists of the middle ages (when the baptistery was transformed into gothic style with the loggias and the hemispherical dome which is superimposed on the pyramid) to end finally in the fourteenth century. It is the largest Italian baptistery. The circumference measures 107 meters and the width of the base wall is about eight feet and the height of 55 meters.

photo.description: On Explore/Flickr Top 500, May 9, 2009 __________________________________________________________________ Arriving at the west entrance to the Cathedral Square(Piazza del Duomo in Italian). This walled area is at the center of Pisa. It is also known as Piazza dei Miracoli ("Square of Miracles"). This square is recognized as one of the main centers for medieval art in the world. Ok, I don't have to tell you what's inside by just looking at the photo, right? Well, its that --and more. Cathedral Square (Piazza del Duomo) Pisa, Tuscany Italy

photo.description: I never thought of the significance of this shot when I snapped on this. This was a sculpture of a dog, with two babies. Those two babies symbolized Romulus and Remus -- traditional founders of Rome and fathered by the God of War. Cathedral Square Pisa, Tuscany Italy

photo.description: On Explore/Flickr Top 500, May 10, 2009 __________________________________________________________________ (From Left to Right) The Baptistry, the Cathedral and the bell tower. That bell tower is known to the world as "The Leaning Tower of Pisa". More on that "leaning" tower, later. I saw some postcard which really has some painting effect rendition of the square, I tried to make some adjustments using a photo editing software to match that one. Well -- this one's close. But the postcard is still better. Cathedral Square Pisa, Tuscany Italy Piazza del Duomo Pisa, Toscana Italia

photo.description: On Explore/Flickr Top 500, May 11, 2009 __________________________________________________________________ Viewed near the Baptistry, about 40 meters west of the Cathedral entrance. The cathedral was constructed in the late 11th century in the medieval times. The cathedral had Romanesque and Byzantine designs. Of all the building's grandeur, overwhelming facade and bronze doors -- the reason why most people know of Pisa and would visit this place -- is the leaning bell tower -- at the back of the cathedral. Pisa Cathedral Cathedral Square Pisa, Tuscany Italy

photo.tags: pisa italy duomo piazzadeimiracoli
photo.title: Duomo, Pisa, Italy

photo.description: The heart of the Piazza del Duomo is, obviously, the Duomo, the medieval cathedral, entitled to Santa Maria Assunta (St. Mary of the Assumption). This is a five-naved cathedral with a three-naved transept. The church is known also as the Primatial, the archbishop of Pisa being a Primate since 1092. The campanile (bell tower) is located behind the cathedral. The last of the three major buildings on the piazza to be built, construction of the bell tower began in 1173 and took place in three stages over the course of 177 years, with the bell-chamber only added in 1372. Five years after construction began, when the building had reached the third floor level, the weak subsoil and poor foundation led to the building sinking on its south side. The building was left for a century, which allowed the subsoil to stabilise itself and prevented the building from collapsing. In 1272, to adjust the lean of the building, when construction resumed, the upper floors were built with one side taller than the other. The seventh and final floor was added in 1319. By the time the building was completed, the lean was approximately 1 degree, or 2.5 feet (0.8m) from vertical. At its greatest, measured prior to 1990, the lean measured approximately 5.5 degrees. As of 2010, this has been reduced to approximately 4 degrees. source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piazza_dei_Miracoli#Duomo

photo.description: La Piazza dei Miracoli de Pisa está formado por el camposanto y el duomo de la ciudad, del que forma parte la razón principal por la que los turistas van a la ciudad, la torre inclinada de Pisa. The Piazza dei Miracolin in Pisa is formed by the camposanto and the duomo of the city, where we locate the main reason why tourists go to the town, the Leaning Tower.
